chapters.title: Introduction
chapters.subTitle: Hiragana and Katakana
chapters.infoSubTitle: Here we will tell you about the alphabets in the Japanese language

blocks.text: Japanese uses two main alphabets — Hiragana and Katakana, each consisting of 46 characters.
Hiragana is primarily used for writing native Japanese words, while Katakana is often used for transcribing foreign words and names.
Additionally, Japanese frequently uses Kanji characters, totaling about two thousand commonly used symbols.

screens.title: Hiragana, Katakana, Kanji — What's the difference?

blocks.text: Hiragana and Katakana are syllabic alphabets representing sounds, whereas Kanji carry meaning.
Learning the correct stroke order is important for writing neat Kanji. Here are the basic rules:

rules: Write strokes from left to right
Write strokes from top to bottom
Most curves and circles are drawn clockwise

blocks.text: Understanding and adhering to the correct stroke order is critically important for writing Japanese characters.

A stroke can end with a hook, a sharp stop, or a gradual brush away.

chapters.title: Dakuon and Handakuon
chapters.subTitle: Dakuon and Handakuon
chapters.infoSubTitle: Here we will tell you about special marks in Hiragana

blocks.text: Having mastered the basic syllables of Hiragana, it’s time to learn about dakuon and handakuon—special marks that alter the sounds of the syllables.

table: か, き, く, け, こ
さ, し, す, せ, そ
た, ち, つ, て, と
は, ひ, ふ, へ, ほ

screens.title: Dakuon ka, ki, ku, ke, ko

blocks.text: By adding special marks called dakuten, which are two short lines, to the syllables, we create new sounds. See how this changes the pronunciation.

screens.title: Dakuon za, ji, zu, ze, zo

blocks.text: Similarly, we add dakuten to syllables starting with 's', turning them into voiced sounds.

screens.title: Choose the hiragana for suzuran (lily of the valley)
Dakuon da, ji, zu, de, do

blocks.text: By adding dakuten to syllables starting with 't', we create another set of voiced sounds.
The syllables じ (ji) and ぢ (ji), as well as ず (zu) and づ (zu), are pronounced the same in modern Japanese. They used to sound different but have merged over time.
Note that じ is most commonly used for 'ji', and ず for 'zu'. The syllables ぢ and づ are rarely used.

rules: じ (ji), ず (zu) - most commonly used

screens.title: Choose the hiragana for dashi (Japanese broth)
Dakuon ba, bi, bu, be, bo

blocks.text: Let's see how to apply dakuten to syllables starting with 'h', turning them into the voiced 'b' sounds.

screens.title: Choose the hiragana for kabuki (Japanese theatre)
Handakuon pa, pi, pu, pe, po

blocks.text: A special line of Hiragana starting with 'は' (ha) can also be combined with another mark, the handakuten, a small circle, which transforms the sounds into 'p'.

screens.title: Choose the romaji for ぱくぱく (eating heartily)

blocks.text: Using special marks significantly changes the meanings of words, underscoring their importance in the Japanese language.

chapters.title: Long Vowels
chapters.subTitle: Long Vowels
chapters.infoSubTitle: Here we will tell you about long vowels

blocks.text: We have previously touched on special signs in Hiragana. Today, we will delve deeper into the study of long vowels. Let's start with the basics — revising the five fundamental vowels.
Let's examine how long vowels can change the meaning of words. This is crucial for proper understanding and avoiding confusion.

rules: おばさん (obasan) - aunt; middle-aged woman

blocks.text: **あ** (a) extends the vowel 'a' in hiragana, creating a long sound, for example, in the word かあ (kaa).
**い** (i) extends the vowel 'i', as in にい (nii).
**う** (u) extends the vowel 'u', as in くう (kuu).
**い** (i) extends the vowel 'e' to 'ei', as in the word せい (sei), and **う** (u) extends the vowel 'o' to 'ou', as in こう (kou).
The topic marker 'wa', used to indicate the subject, is written as は (ha) but pronounced as 'wa'. This is a unique rule in the Japanese language.

rules: わたし は がくせい です (Watashi wa gakusei desu) - I am a student.

chapters.title: Long Consonants
chapters.subTitle: Long Consonants
chapters.infoSubTitle: Here we will tell you about long consonants

blocks.text: In the previous lesson, we discussed long vowels. Now, let's turn our attention to long consonants in Japanese, which play an equally important role.
Doubling of consonants is indicated by the small 'tsu' (っ) character placed before a consonant, creating a pause in the word and lengthening the consonant sound.
Examine the examples of using the standard 'tsu' (つ) and the small 'tsu' (っ):
Note that the small 'tsu' (っ) is not used before vowels and certain consonants such as **な**, **に**, **ぬ**, **ね**, **の**. In these cases, the symbol **ん** (n) is used to lengthen the sounds.

The word 'hello' is written as こんにちは (konnichiwa), where the last character is **は** (ha), not **わ** (wa). This is because the phrase was originally longer and used the particle **は** as part of the greeting.
Remember, the Japanese topic marker, despite being written as **は** (ha), is always pronounced 'wa'.

chapters.title: Dakuten and Handakuten in Katakana
chapters.subTitle: Dakuten and Handakuten
chapters.infoSubTitle: Here we will tell you about the special signs in Katakana

blocks.text: After covering all the Katakana syllables, it's time to learn about the special signs used with these symbols. Let's explore which syllables can use Dakuten and Handakuten.

table: カ, キ, ク, ケ, コ
サ, シ, ス, セ, ソ
タ, チ, ツ, テ, ト
ハ, ヒ, フ, ヘ, ホ

screens.title: Dakuten ka, ki, ku, ke, ko

blocks.text: By adding Dakuten, special marks in the form of two short lines, to the Katakana syllables, we form the voiced versions of these syllables. Observe how the pronunciation changes.

screens.title: Dakuten za, ji, zu, ze, zo

blocks.text: Similarly, we can apply Dakuten to syllables starting with 's' to transform them into voiced sounds.

screens.title: Dakuten da, ji, zu, de, do

blocks.text: Dakuten can also be added to syllables starting with 't', creating another set of voiced sounds.
The syllables ジ (ji) and ヂ (ji), as well as ズ (zu) and ヅ (zu), are pronounced the same in modern Japanese. These sounds were once pronounced differently but have merged over time.
ジ is most commonly used for 'ji' and ズ for 'zu', while ヂ and ヅ are significantly less common.

rules: ジ (ji) and ズ (zu) are most commonly used
ヂ (ji) and ヅ (zu) are rarely used

screens.title: Dakuten ba, bi, bu, be, bo

blocks.text: Let's explore how applying Dakuten to syllables starting with 'h' changes them to the voiced 'b' sounds.

screens.title: Handakuten pa, pi, pu, pe, po

blocks.text: A special series in Katakana starts with ハ (ha). By adding the Handakuten, a small circle, we change the sounds to 'p'.

chapters.title: Additional Katakana Sounds
chapters.subTitle: Additional Sounds
chapters.infoSubTitle: Here we will tell you about additional sounds in Katakana

blocks.text: In Japanese, the 'r' and 'l' sounds are considered identical, as are 'h' and 'f' sounds. Therefore, instead of the 'l' sound, the row for 'r' is used, and for the 'f' sound, the row for 'h' is used. To address the use of the 'f' sound, a new form of notation combining vowels with reduced fonts was adopted.
The sound 'フ' (fu) can be combined with reduced vowel characters to create the sounds 'fa', 'fi', 'fe', and 'fo'.

You might wonder: if there is only the katakana 'ワ' for 'wa', how are other syllables with the letter 'v' formed, such as 'vo' or 've'? Or do they not exist at all? In Japanese, they indeed do not exist (and are not distinct from the 'b' sound), but they are still present for writing foreign words.
In Katakana, there is only the syllable 'ワ' for 'wa' (wa), but to create sounds with 'v', we use vowels based on 'ウ' (u):

blocks.text: To create sounds of the 'v' group in Katakana, characters based on 'ウ' with the addition of a dakuten are used, making the sound harsher:
Japanese rarely use the hard 'v' sounds due to pronunciation difficulties.
To express the sound 'che' in Katakana, use the character 'チェ'. This allows for the correct recording of foreign words.
For the sounds 'di' and 'du' in Katakana, use the characters 'ディ' and 'ドゥ' respectively.
To write the sound 'je' and 'she', use the characters 'ジェ'. and 'シェ'.
To express the sounds 'ti' and 'tu', use the characters 'ティ' and 'トゥ'.

chapters.title: Yoon
chapters.subTitle: や, ゆ, よ
chapters.infoSubTitle: Here we will tell you about Yoon.

blocks.text: Today we will delve into the last rule of Hiragana, but first let's revisit these three special letters:
There are miniature versions of や (ya), ゆ (yu), and よ (yo) that, when pronounced, blend with the preceding letter to form a single sound. Let's compare the standard や (ya) and the miniature ゃ (ya).
The Yoon elements (や, ゆ, よ) can combine with characters that end with the 'i' sound. Let's start with combinations of き (ki) and ぎ (gi).
The letters shi (し) and ji (じ) can also form Yoon with the letters ゃ, ゅ, ょ, creating sounds like sha, shu, sho and ja, ju, jo.

screens.title: Choose the hiragana for jū gyo ui n (employee).

blocks.text: Letters チ (chi) and ヂ (ji) can be used to create sounds like cha, chu, cho and dza, dzu, dzo. In modern Japanese, the letter ヂ is often replaced with ジ.

screens.title: Choose the hiragana for te chou (notebook).

blocks.text: Combinations of ni (に) and mi (み) with miniature symbols allow the creation of complex sounds nya, nyu, nyo and mya, myu, myo.
Letter ri (り) combines with miniature vowels to form sounds rya, ryu, ryo.

screens.title: Choose the hiragana for ryōri ni n (chef).

blocks.text: Use the letters hi (ひ), bi (び), and pi (ぴ) in combination with miniature vowels to create Yoon sounds.
Examine how these sounds change the meaning of a word depending on the context.

chapters.title: Yoon in Katakana
chapters.subTitle: ヤ, ユ, ヨ
chapters.infoSubTitle: Here we will tell you about yoon in Katakana.

blocks.text: In this lesson, we will explore the features of yoon in Katakana, starting with three key characters:
There are smaller forms of ヤ (ya), ユ (yu), and ヨ (yo). In pronunciation, these characters combine with a preceding Katakana ending in the 'i' sound, forming a single, complex sound.

rules: キヤ(kiya) - does not exist in Japanese

blocks.text: Let's see how the yoon characters ヤ (ya), ユ (yu), and ヨ (yo) combine with Katakana ending in 'i'. We'll start with キ (ki) and ギ (gi).
The next example shows combinations of shi (シ) and ji (ジ) with smaller characters, forming complex sounds.

Now let's look at how ni (ニ) and mi (ミ) combine with smaller characters to create sounds like nya, nyu, nyo and mya, myu, myo.
